description: From French calamine, from Medieval Latin calamīna, from Latin cadmīa, ultimately from Ancient Greek Κᾰδμείᾱ (Kadmeíā), from Κάδμος (Kádmos, “Cadmus”) + -εια (-eia, “-ia: forming related substances”). Doublet of cadmia, calaminaris, and lapis calaminaris.

entries.meaning: A pink form of zinc oxide formed as a byproduct of zinc sublimation, now used in skin lotions.
examples: ...Poison Ivy, Lord,'ll make you itchYou're gonna need an oceanOf calamine lotionYou'll be scratchin' like a houndThe minute you start to mess around...

entries.meaning: (mineralogy) Synonym of hemimorphite, an orthorhombic-pyramidal mineral containing zinc.

verbs.description: calamine (third-person singular simple present calamines, present participle calamining, simple past and past participle calamined)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To coat or treat with calamine.
